channel.title: Hi there! on Mateusz Kapusta @Wesenheit
channel.description: Recent content in Hi there! on Mateusz Kapusta @Wesenheit

item.title: IrisML - Neural Posterior Estimation for Spectral Energy Distribution fitting
item.description:
• Authors: Mateusz Kapusta
  • Journal: ICML 2025: Machine Learning for Astrophysics workshop Link

Fast and reliable real-time inference for astronomical data? Now possible with Simulation-Based Inference.

item.title: HST pre-imaging of a free-floating planet candidate microlensing event
item.description:
• Authors: Mateusz Kapusta, Przemysław Mróz, OGLE and KMTNet collaborations.
  • Journal: Astronomy & Astrophysics Link

Are free-floating planets really free-floating or bound on wider orbits?

item.title: About
item.description:
I am a physics student at the University of Warsaw. My scientific career has been largely focused on developing software for a variety of scientific tasks, primarily in Bayesian modeling and High-Performance Computing (HPC).

In high school, I competed in several scientific Olympiads, where I had the honor of representing my country at the International Olympiad on Astronomy and Astrophysics. Today, I remain committed to this beautiful Olympic tradition and serve as a judge in various competitions.

item.title: Approximate Bayesian Computation with Wrocław trams
item.description:
Introduction

Recently, I presented some results from the field of Simulation-Based Inference at the Statistical Journal Club at the Astronomical Observatory. While modern neural networks allow the creation of some incredible models that allow for the Likelihood Free Inference (LFI), there are also some more old-school examples from the field of statistics. Those were usually labeled as the Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC) methods. Here, I would like to write something about the classical implementation and apply it to one of my favorite problems known as the German tanks problem (although here there will be trams).

item.title: Search for dormant black holes in the OGLE data
item.description:
• Authors: Mateusz Kapusta, Przemek Mróz
  • Journal: Acta Astronomica Link

Are there any black holes that are dormant (no X-ray signature) and reside in ellipsoidal binaries? Spoiler: probably not.

item.title: GMVAE clustering applied to RNA sequencing
item.description: Traditional clustering methods typically rely on the raw, observed features of data. However, we can often achieve better results by using Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) to create an embedded representation of the data first.

item.title: LSTM vs Tolkien
item.description:
Introduction

This notebook is greatly inspired by this notebook by G. Negrini. Please check out his website, as he make really good content. In original notebook, the Keras library was used. This approach is based on duo Jax + Haiku from DeepMind. We will try to distinguish between drug names and Tolkien characters using simple LSTM model, surprisingly it isn’t as easy as one can think. If you want to challenge yourself, here is popular website with great quiz.
